Clive14

Of course, creationists did lose philosophically & scientifically, BUT they may win politically by eroding the "wall of separation between church & state". Creationism is very much a serious political movement regardless of how ridiculous it is as pseudoscience. So I do take it seriously in that respect.
It is tempting here to point out that this is a mainly American problem and why should the rest of the world care or take it seriously? The USA's domination of the sciences is waning. This may in part be due to religious fundamentalism in that country resulting in ever fewer "world class" scientists there. Europe and Asia are happily filling the hole left by the decline in American science.
 
 However, there is a very real threat that the sickness of scientific denial and growth of extremist religion in an age when it ought to be in decline could spread to Europe at least. Here we generally do not have laws creating a separation of church and state (France is an exception, but I cannot think of others) and so we would not have that protection against campaigns to teach religious myths. All of us, American or not, ought to take the threat of the American "religious right" very seriously therefore.

 Walking-fish:
 I see 3 things that contribute to the rise of creationism:
 1) lack of vigilence about separating church & state
 2) lack of good public education (esp in the sciences)
 3) extreme poverty where people turn to fanatical religion for a sense of hope
 
 In America our declining public education system, which some politicians want to privatize, and widening gap between rich & poor is making more & more people susceptible to the sophisms of very clever creationist pundits. The establishment clause of our first amendment is the one safe guard that has prevented the large scale teaching of creationism in our schools, but we can't expect the supreme court to protect us from our declining social milieu indefinitely.

 Walking-fish:
 I'll take a stab at this one. I'll set aside two categories of unsubstantiated creationist claims. The first group includes that which has been definitely proven false, the second includes that which has neither been proven false nor backed up with evidence. 
 
 The following notions have been proven false:
 1) A young Earth of only 6,000 yrs (since the age of the Earth has been established at 4 1/2 billion yrs)
 2) A world wide flood 4500 yrs ago (only local floods have been substantiated)
 3) The coexistence of humans & dinos (dinos went extinct 65 million yrs ago and the humans share a common ancestor with the chimp @ 5 to 6 million yrs ago)
 4) any number of alleged inconsistencies that YECs have pointed out concerning errors in dating, since there is too much concilience with dates from many different methods.
 
 So, basically, the YEC claims have largely been falsified. Now for those which have been neither falsified nor substantiated:
 1) the existence of an Intelligent Designer
 2) God as the prime mover of the universe initiating the "Big Bang"
 3) the tinkering God of the progressive creationists or theistic evolutionists who "fine tunes" things to help them progress from one taxon to the next.
 
 While the YECs are totally out to lunch, this second list of claims, while not proven wrong, is still without any corroborating evidence so it lies outside of science and shouldn't be mentioned in the public school science classroom. The evidence for evolution, OTOH, is too involved for someone to include in just one post like this. So I'll stop here.

 Well, since you weren't actually asking serious questions I didn't think you expected serious answers. If you'ld like some...
 
 How has creationism been proven wrong? LIke I said, the details depend on which version you espouse. YEC, the most popular sort, can easily be disproven by showing that the universe is more than 8000 years old. This has shown through ratios of isotopes in nature, and the fact that we can see things that are more than 8000 light years away. IF YEC isn't your flavor of creationism then please supply the details of what you do believe.
 
 Who's abserved evolution? Lots of people. There have been countless lab experiments involving bacteria, fruit flies, mice, etc that demonstrate evolution. The book "Beak of the Finch" gives a wonderful account of evolution observed in nature. And of course the fossil record allows us to see evolution throughout earth's history.
 
 What are we evolving into? Impossible to say, of course. Mutations are random, and the future environment is unknown, so we have no way to know ahead of time what, exactly, is going to happen. Could we die out? Sure, exitnction is part of evolution.
 
 I'm afraid I don't know what you're asking for in your last question. If there are so many what?

 oh ya how did caves form? did it just magiaclly evolve from the ground or do you htink some drastic amount of water ran through and carved it out. 

 caves form from water seeping past hard rock and washing out the softer rock between it. this type of cave takes years to form, and cannot be formed by suddenly being emmersed in water. this type of cave can only be formed by the gradual eating away of the soft rocks over a long period of time. they can also form by small shifts in the tectonic plats, creating a gap between rocks. the fact that we have caves that are older than the proposed time of the biblical flood is proof that such a flood never took place. a flood causes sediment to fill into any areas that water could get into.

 What are we evolving into? Impossible to say, of course. Mutations are random, and the future environment is unknown, so we have no way to know ahead of time what, exactly, is going to happen. Could we die out? Sure, exitnction is part of evolution.

Looking at these pictures, something suddenly struck me: we humans appear to be a neotenous species, for the more human skulls look far more "baby-like" than the chimp and Australopithecus skulls. Does anyone know if this is recognised by the biological community as being the case, or am I just letting my imagination get the better of me?
Yes. The idea is recognized and generally accepted in the biological community. It is a relatively recent idea that wasn't formulated until the discovery of the hox gene complexes, which gave rise to the whole biological sub specialty of evo devo (evolutionary developmental biology). A change in one of these genes could significantly alter the developmental pathways of an embryo, including retention of juvenile characteristics in a sexually mature individual. You can read about it in Endless Forms Most Beautiful: The New Science of Evo Devo and the Making of the Animal Kingdom

Looking at these pictures, something suddenly struck me: we humans appear to be a neotenous species, for the more human skulls look far more "baby-like" than the chimp and Australopithecus skulls. Does anyone know if this is recognised by the biological community as being the case, or am I just letting my imagination get the better of me?

 
 Yes, it is widely accepted and, although it has gained additional support and interest fairly recently, the idea goes back to the very early 1900s.
 
 
"Humans as Neotenic Animals
 One of the first scientists to conceptualize the potential evolutionary importance of heterochrony - of the effect of differential rates of reproductive and physical development - was the Dutch embryologist and developmental anatomist Louis L. Bolk. Although his basic, descriptive embryological studies and publications were well known and very respected through the latter decades of the nineteenth and into the early twentieth century, Bolk did not publish the first of his few but influential treatises on the subject of the interplay between development rates until 1915. His grand synthesis and overview appeared in print in 1926, just four years before his death at the age of sixty-four. Building on the suggestions of the early-nineteenth-century French naturalists and comparative anatomists Georges-Louis de Buffon and Etienne Geoffroy Saint-Hillaire, who had long before recognized the extreme similarities in skull shape between adult humans and juvenile apes, partuclarly orangutans, Bolk was determined to demonstrate the existence of such similarites in all aspects of adult human and juvenile ape anatomy.
 
 For example, one of Bolk's favorite examples had to do with the angle between the plane of the base of the skull, through which the spinal cord passes, and the plane of the face. As is typical of mammals in general, in human and ape fetuses the angle between the base of the skull and the face is essentially ninety degrees, a right angle. This is a pretty tight angle, which Bolk described as producing an extreme flexure between the facial skeleton and the base of the skull. In addition, because the base of the skull faces down relative to the face, the fetus's head sits atop the vertebral column and the facial skeleton lies at a right angle to it.
 
 In apes,as in most other mammals, the angle between the skull base and the facial skeleton opens up and the spatial relationship of these regions changes. With growth, the base of the skull rotates away from the enlarging snout, with the result that the hole through which the spinal cord exits the skull - the foramen magnum - and the two points of articulation on the skull base for the first vertebra - the occipital chondyles - point backward to varying degrees. But in humans the severe angle between the face and the base of the skull does not change with physical growth. As in the fetus, the adult human's foramen magnum and its associated occipital chondyles continue to lie centrally on the base of the skull. In turn, this means both that the adult skull continues to sit right on top of the vertical vertebral column and that the face continues to lie at a right angle to the vertebral column. Of special note, of course, is that the orientation of the vertebral column in humans is associated with their bipedal form of locomotion. As Bolk envisioned it, an adult human is essentially an upright-walking embryo. And if this reflects a prolongation of juvenile growth rates into adulthood, then humans are indeed neotenic.
 (Sudden Origins: Fossils, Genes, and the Emergence of Species, Jeffrey H. Schwartz, John Wiley & Sons, 1999, p134-135)
 

 
 And even the fact that humans have much larger brains than other primates is explained by neoteny.
 
 
"If there is one important developmental trait that distinguishes humans from the rest of the animal kingdom, it is our retention of the fetal neural growth rate. Like human brains, apes' brains have a high growth rate before birth. After birth, however, this rate slows greatly in the apes; in contrast, humans have rapid brain growth for about two years. During early postnatal development, we add approximately 250,000 neurons per minute. The ratio of brain weight to body weight at birth is also similar for great apes and humans. By the time humans are adults, however, the ratio for humans is literally "off the chart" at 3.5 that of apes.
 
 At the cellular level, we find that no fewer than 30,000 synapses per second per square centimeter of cortex are formed during the first few years of life. ...
 
 The prodigious rate of continued neuron production has important consequences. Portmann, Gould, and Montagu have each made the claim that we are essentially extrauterine fetuses for the first year of life. Our actual gestation period is 21 months if you follow the charts of ape maturity. In other words, humans are at 21 months what other apes are at birth. Our "premature birth" is an evolutionary compromise between maternal pelvic width and the infant's head circumference and lung maturity. The mechanism for the retention of the fetal neural growth rate has been called hypermorphosis - the phyletic extension of development beyond its ancestral state.
 (Developmental Biology: Seventh Edition, Scott F. Gilbert, Sinaur Associates Inc., 2003, p408)
